p: Variation in seed mass in the variable dispersal scenario caused a bias towards competitive superiority of larger seeds due to the kernel effect, such that coexistence and resilience under changing conditions were severely impaired. The modifying addition of the SMSN trade-off in the trade-off scenario, parameterised as far as possible by empirical data, buffered much of the predicted diversity loss by reducing the unrealistically strong fitness differences caused by the kernel effect. The trade-off between seed mass and seed number had an equalising effect [ 25] that allowed for higher levels of coexistence during both stable climates as well as under climate change.
